page.title: 08 Religion in Barham.
page.content: The parish church was named after St. John the baptist.It is known there was a church of some sort in Barham as early as 800 AD;it is mentioned in the Domesday Book.Records of rectors began in 1280.The earliest parts of the present building are from the 12th century.Inside you may find a 14th century font with a Jacobean cover and three brasses.One is said to be the earliest full length brass of a civilian in Kent.A window of St.George killing the dragon honours the signallers who camped on the downs during the Great War.Over 200 people can be seated in the church but only just over 100 attend services regularly every month.There is also a Methodist Chapel which is used by the Parish church Sunday School.The children spend an hour there,partly in separate classes,and in a service.
